awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exploring the geography of sodium as a catalyst in terrestrial communities and ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
Essential services performed by Earth's ecosystems, such as decomposing detritus into nutrients, transforming plants into meat, creating and aerating fertile soil, arise from the combined actions of millions of organisms. Each of these organisms, from bacteria to butterflies to bison, best contribute to these services when they consume a healthy diet, which includes access to minerals, especially sodium. Sodium is a critical mineral for ecosystems because plants are generally low in sodium but the things that eat them, from fungi to grasshoppers, require it to grow and reproduce.  Thus every plant eater must search out, harvest, and hang onto quantities of sodium, and will go to extremes eating carcasses, soil, and urine, to get that quota. Moreover, sodium is not uniformly distributed on the landscape.  It falls as dilute ocean water near the coasts, it clings to clay soils but is leached from sandy soils, and it is distributed by the truckload to keep snowy roads free from ice. This project combines these two facts, that sodium is potentially one of the most important drivers of the health of plant consumers, and that sodium is geographically patchy, to predict the abundance and services of plant consumers across the North American continent. This research should lead to better prediction of such disparate phenomena as why grasshoppers are bigger crop pests in one county than another; why carbon is better stored in inland soils than those near the ocean; and why termite damage claims are centered along the Gulf Coast of the U.S. and up into the Mid-Atlantic states.

To evaluate this proposition, the project combines two methods. The first maps the distribution of sodium across and within North American ecosystems and focuses on the easily accessible and widespread grasslands, old fields, and roadsides, and the invertebrates that live in them. The goal in Year 1 is to explore the basic hypothesis that as soil supplies of sodium increase - due to deposition from the ocean, high clay content, or because they are salted every winter - plants will not be affected but the animals that eat them (and the predators that eat the plant consumers) will. Thus the first year will generate a map of the abundance and activity of invertebrates above and belowground, and the degree to which both track sodium supply (and other nutrients). Then, in Year 2 and 3, these correlations will be put to the test experimentally in 6 grasslands from the central and eastern U.S. At each grassland, 50 meter square plots will be fertilized with a dilute sodium concentrations mimicking the slightly salty rainfall of the island of Puerto Rico; smaller plots will receive sodium mimicking that deposited on a regular basis by every animal as urine. By carefully tracking where the sodium goes, and how it boosts the numbers and activity of invertebrates, the project will test how animal health and vigor across North America is influenced by sodium supply. By examining how pollinators, herbivores, and detritivores respond, the project will test the transformative idea that sodium is a catalyst for ecosystem services.

Grasslands?in all their forms, from pristine, to pasture, to agricultural field?make up 40% of Earth's land surface. Understanding the rules by which grasslands produce plants, and how grassland consumers?from fungi and insects to cattle and bison?then benefit is of great import to the health of humans as well as the rest of the planet.

Our project explored how three abiotic features of ecosystems--their temperature, precipitation, and elemental chemistry?can be used to predict the geography of grasssland ecology across North America. We focused especially on one element, sodium, that is a main component of table salt (i.e., NaCl). Sodium is unique among the 25 or so elements required for life, as plants have little need for sodium to run their metabolic machinery, while it is absolutely vital to animals and fungi. This sets up a problem for things that eat low sodium plants: they must reach a quota of sodium in their bodies that is often 100 times more concentrated than the plants they feed upon. When you combine this fact with the widespread geographic variation in the amount of sodium you find in North American ecosystems, you get the kernal of an explanation as to why plants vary in their sodium content, why the abundance of herbivores (and *their* predators) vary from place to place, and why the amount of damage plants suffer from those herbivores also vary. 

Allow me to describe a few of the things we learned. 

Early in the project, grad student (now Doctor) Rebecca Prather explored how temperature and sodium demands were linked, using one of the most common consumers in grasslands: ants. Working from a fundamental understanding of how animal cells and tissues work, Rebecca predicted, and subsequently discovered, that as temperatures increase the demand for sodium by a grassland ant community *accelerated*. This means that a small increase in temperature in a cool ecosystem leads to a smaller increase in sodium demand that the same temperature rise in a warm ecosystem. As (we shall see below) sodium availability is a big constraint on the activity of consumers like ants, this also suggests that Earth's heating will grow that constraint. Just as atheletes suffer cramping when heat causes them to lose sodium through sweat (and require sodium-rich sports drink), so does the activity of herbivores likely suffer from sodium deprivation as the planet warms. 

A second study involved visiting 54 grasslands, from Florida and Texas to the high mountains of Colorado and open prairies of Minnesota. In each, we took a "snapshot" of the ecosystem, measuring the chemistry of the soil and plants, and counting the abundance and biomass of the plants and insects in each. In addition, we "pulsed" a series of plots with the amount of sodium you would find in cow urine, to explore the response of the local insect community. This study yielded an abundance of results, a few of which I summarize here. First, the chemical recipe of grassland plants was surprisingly variable?not all grasslands provide the same nutrition per bite?due to a variety of factors, including the chemistry of the soil, presence/absence of cattle, and the total amount of grass produced per year (more on that later). Second, sodium pulses regularly attract insects after only 24-48 hours, and this attraction strengthens as sodium availability declines. Third, the food web supported by grasslands tends to become more "top-heavy", supporting more predators like spiders and robberflies relative to herbivores like caterpillars and grasshoppers, as sodium availability and temperatures increase. All told, these studies show how temperature, precipitation, and sodium availability have effects that spread a grassland's food web, and predict changes in those food webs as one travels across North America. 

A third study built upon a long-term project at the Konza prairie in Kansas. Investigators there, who were mentors of the project post doc, Dr. Ellen Welti, had accrued a long record of samples of Konza's plants and grasshoppers. Ellen decided to explore how the grasshopper community at Konza had changed, and how it responded to changing nutritional status of the plants themselves. She found that grasshoppers on this pristine prairie had declined over 2% per year over the past two decades, and that these declines coincided with a drops in the nutrition a grasshopper would gain from a bite of Konza grass. Disturbingly, the nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and sodium content of Konza's grasses had also declined. This nutrient dilution likely resulted from the doubling of grass biomass over the same time. In effect, Konza was growing more, less quality grass, a result likely linked to the increase in CO2 and temperature, both spurring on more grassland productivity, and creating "green deserts". This has profound implications for the ability of Earth's grasslands to feed its consumers into the future.
